text: This is one of those country cemeteries that would be an ordinary pasture without the grim slabs. AUDREY, 30s, in a flowing dress that gently rolls like wa in the breeze, stands next to... CHEYENNE, 8, an adorable little likeness of her mother. Together, they’re a symbol of all that’s beautiful about life. They gaze blankly at a casket in an open grave, pondering mortality.
We should go. She puts her hands on Cheyenne’s shoulders. Steers her to a single car parked on the gravel road.
How come everyone left so soon?
Probably had things to do.
There weren’t that many people.
Grandpa was pretty old.
Then it seems like he would have had more friends than anyone.
Most of his friends have already died, sweetie.

The house is small with add-ons, isolated and derelict, w a couple of dilapidated buildings behind it, an old barn machine shed. Other than the dusty road leading to it, it surrounded by woodlands. Audrey's car pulls up the gravel driveway, stops behind t house. Audrey and Cheyenne climb out, scan the area.
Have I ever been here before?
Yes. You were too young to remember. I usually visited while you were with grandma and grandpa. They approach the barn like they’re walking in the park.
I thought this was my grandpa.
No, this was my grandpa. Cheyenne drifts toward a field as Audrey reaches the door AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t go too far, Cheyenne. And don’t get your dress dirty.

Audrey steps cautiously into the dingy building. It’s fil with a lifetime’s worth of dusty old farm equipment. A CO OF ROPE hangs on the wall. Audrey touches an old harness, smacks the dust off her ha

Cheyenne approaches a large woodpile. When she gets close a covey of quail suddenly erupts from the pile, their TWEETING filling the air. Caught off guard, Cheyenne falls back onto the ground. Sh watches in wonder as the birds fill nearby trees. Audrey steps out of the barn to see what’s going on.
What did you do? Cheyenne climbs off the ground and shrugs.
Nothing. I just walked to the woodpile.
Well, come away from there. Don’t bother the birds. Cheyenne makes her way back.
I didn’t. Audrey brushes Cheyenne’s dress off.
I told you not to get dirty and it’s the first thing you did.
I’m sorry. She points to a dusty spot on Audrey’s dress. Audrey brus it off.
I guess I should have told myself not to get dirty too. They share a laugh. Audrey puts her arm around Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) Come on. Let’s look around some more.
Are we going into the house?
I have to get the key from Mr. Pendleton. INT. BOBBY’S OFFICE - DAY 5 BOBBY, 30s, affluent and sleazy, paces behind his desk.

Those water rights have been in his family since the eighteen hundreds. We now see the two men Bobby speaks to... First there’s JAWARI, late 30s, an African-American with moustache. His face has a gentle quality. Then there’s RAINY, 30s, slouched in his chair. His eyes would be completely empty except for a sinister tinge.
The old man’s personally owned them since nineteen-thirty-nine. It’s going to take some persuasion. Bobby leans over his desk to bring full attention to what he’s about to emphasize.
I want you to persuade him. Do you two know each other? Jawari and Rainy look each other over.
I’ve seen him around.
I got a friend who said he bought a skimpy bag of weed from him. Jawari stiffens, offended.
I don’t sell skimpy bags.
Had a bunch of stems in it.
Bullshit. Bobby dismisses them with a wave as he sits.
All right, all right. Jawari, Rainy. Rainy, Jawari. Can you two work together? Rainy leans on Bobby’s desk with a smart aleck smirk.
Hey, man, I’m a professional. Bobby looks at Jawari for an answer. Jawari nods.
All right, listen. I just want you to loosen the old man up. Do not kill him.
When do you want it done?
Tomorrow. Around noon. Just hold him there. I’1l drop by later with the papers.
What if he gives us trouble? Bobby flashes Rainy a sharp look.
Listen, asshole. What did I just say? Do not kill him. He can’t sign any papers dead.
I was just asking. He might have a shotgun or something.
He’s in his nineties. Can’t you handle a guy in his nineties? EXT. TRAILER PARK -— DAY 6 The back door of a tiny trailer opens. Audrey leans out, hanging off the doorframe.

Cheyenne! Dinner’s ready! She retreats, closing the door, almost like a cuckoo cloc INT. AUDREY’S TRAILER - LIVING ROOM - DAY 7 Audrey turns from the back door, makes her way through th modest family area and to the...
She stops over the stove where a pot of soup simmers. Gra ladle and stirs. Cheyenne rushes through the front door, breathing heavily carrying a piece of paper with tape on it.
Why are you out of breath?
James and Chris were chasing me and Lucia. They said they were going to throw us in the pond.
Oh really? Go wash up. Cheyenne starts for the bathroom.
What's that? Cheyenne hurries back, still hyper, holding the paper out
It was on the door. What’s for dinner? She hands Audrey the paper and scurries off.

Vegetable soup. Audrey examines the paper. It’s a FINAL EVICTION NOTICE. frowns, looks up. Cheyenne’s already in the bathroom with water running. Audrey calls out. AUDREY (CONT’D) What did you think of the farm? Did you like it?
Yeah! It was okay! Audrey pulls two bowls from the cupboard.
Just okay? Cheyenne comes back to the kitchen as Audrey fills a bowl
It was fun to run around. There’s lots of places to go. They sit at the table to eat. Audrey nudges a package of crackers toward Cheyenne.

There's crackers if you want. Cheyenne grabs some, crushes them over her soup.  AUDREY (CONT’D) So, you know, Grandpa was kind of a hermit in his old age. I’m probably the only family he really had any contact with. She waits for a reaction. Cheyenne sips her soup. AUDREY (CONT’D) He might leave me something in his will.
Really? Like what?
Like, I don’t know. Mr. Pendleton hinted he might leave me the farm.
Really? Audrey hesitates, trying to be tactful.
It has a lot more space than the trailer.
Do you have to work tonight? Audrey’s a little surprised by Cheyenne’s disinterest.
Yes.
Who’s watching me?
Lucia’s mom. Cheyenne looks up, grinning. Audrey smiles. AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t let the boys throw you in the pond. Cheyenne giggles.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 8.
It’s a small all-night place. Audrey finishes scribbling an order for a TRUCK DRIVER at the counter.
Would you like more coffee?
No thanks.

I‘ll put this right in. She glides to a table as TWO CUSTOMERS leave behind scatt empty dishes. AUDREY (CONT’D) Thanks, guys. She stacks dirty plates. Notices the tip. She picks up... maybe a dollar and a half in change. Total. She’s stunned 10 INT. MARTY’S OFFICE - LATER 10 MARTY, the owner, 50s, sits at his desk looking over tax papers, confused and frustrated. Audrey knocks.
Got a minute? Marty glances at his watch.
A minute is about all you got. I’m stressin’ over this tax mess. This is my last extension. Audrey sits across from him.
I’m having some hard times financially. Marty gestures at the tax papers.
Aren’t we all?
I need to make some extra money.
That’s what tips are for. You want more money? Flirt with the customers more.
I’m not asking for a raise. I was just wondering if I could get some extra hours.
I’m looking at cutting back hours as it is.
I got a kid, Marty.
Please don’t give me a sob story. I get at least one of those a week. Marty goes back to work, ignoring her. Defeated, Audrey starts to leave. Marty sighs, rubs his face.
All right, look. You need some extra cash and I need to relax. We're a match made in heaven. He shrugs, wondering if she gets his meaning. She gets it she doesn’t appreciate it. She summons courage.
You owe me overtime pay.
(annoyed) I told you, you'll get your overtime when I get my tax refund.
I know you have the money. You just bought a new car.
So we’ve come to this? You wanna play hard ball? Might I remind you that there’s no actual record of this alleged overtime. Audrey stares in disbelief. It quickly turns to anger.
I knew you would do this.  11 12 10.
You all agreed to it.
You changed all our time-sheets.
You signed them.
What choice did we have?
I’m gonna pay you. I just can’t do it right now. You'll just have to wait... like we agreed. She turns away, speaking under her breath.
Asshole.
I heard that. That’s a code of conduct violation. I could dock your pay for that. She walks away while he’s talking.

Jawari parks his car a few spaces over from Rainy’s truck Rainy climbs out, clumsily carrying a rifle and a handgun all while holding onto a plastic ring for a sixpack of be INT. JAWARI’S CAR - DAY 12 Jawari watches stunned as Rainy awkwardly climbs into his car. Once settled, Rainy holds up the sixpack.
Wanna beer?
What the fuck is wrong with you?
What? It’s just beer.
I’m talking about you carrying guns right out in the open.  11.
Nobody saw me. (re: the rifle) Besides, this isn’t a gun. It’s a rifle.
You really think we need an assault rifle for an old man?
Here’s your weapon. He gives Jawari the handgun.
A six shooter?
It's a thirty-eight. That’s respectable.
How come I get a six shooter like I’m a fuckin’ cowboy and you get a semi automatic rifle?
Man, ‘cause that’s what I got. That was my daddy’s gun.
Daddy? You call your old man daddy?
What is your problem? I just thought we’d have a beer together. Jawari glances at the chamber.
Where’s the bullets? Rainy digs them out of his pocket.
I got your bullets right here, man. He pulls out six bullets, hands them to Jawari.
Six bullets? That’s all I get?  13 12.
How many do you need? It’s a six shooter. Besides, we’re not supposed to kill anyone, remember? Jawari stuffs the bullets in his jacket pocket.
You got any weed? Jawari gives Rainy an annoyed look.
It’s all stems, man.

Oh, come on, man. You know I was just messin’ with you about that. Besides, I know your personal stash will be the good shit. Jawari hesitates, then pulls a fat bag from his pocket. R grins from ear to ear.
That's what I’m talkin’ about. INT. MR. PENDLETON’S OFFICE - DAY 13 MR. PENDLETON, 80s, a relaxed folksy lawyer, removes a ke from a drawer. He steps around his desk to meet Audrey an Cheyenne.
This is Mr. Pendleton. He’s handling Grandpa's estate. Mr. Pendleton smiles at Cheyenne.
My, I never knew he had such a pretty great granddaughter. Cheyenne smiles.
My great grandpa had an estate?
Yes, he owned eighty acres. Cheyenne has no idea how much that is, but it sounds impressive.  13.
Wow, that’s a lot.
Yes, it is. He looks up at Audrey as he hands her the key. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Do you have any plans for it if he leaves it to you? Audrey stares at the key, cautious about her words.
It needs a lot of work. I probably couldn’t sell it for much. I’ve been wondering if it wouldn’t be cheaper to live there. Cheyenne looks up. This is news to her.

Well, the will won't be officially executed until next week. We'll go over the specifics then. Audrey glances down at Cheyenne, smiles awkwardly. Mr. Pendleton picks up on her distress. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) I was at the funeral. I don’t know if you saw me.
Yeah, thanks. And thanks for the flowers.
You know, I worked with your grandfather on my very first job. We were just boys.
I didn’t know that. Mr. Pendleton smiles at the thought.
Picking the best corn we ever ate. Audrey smiles. Mr. Pendleton turns to Cheyenne.  14. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) The first time I saw your mother, she was younger than you are now.
Really?
And do you know, she ran away from me? Cheyenne giggles. Audrey tries to recall.
Seriously?

I stopped by for a visit one day. They said you took time to warm up to people. After about ten minutes, I caught you spying on me from the corner of the house. Another ten minutes and you were offering me a cup of pretend tea. Audrey and Cheyenne laugh. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) By the time I left, you were hanging onto my neck. They had to pull you off me.
So I warmed up to you finally?
Oh yeah. You were a clever one too. You used a coffee can lid for a Frisbee and got it stuck on the roof. You tied a rope to a baseball mitt and threw it up there.
Now that sounds like me.
Did she get it down?

She sure did. As the laughter subsides, Mr. Pendleton gives Audrey a sympathetic look.  15. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) An answer has no purpose without a problem, you know. Audrey stares at him, perceiving he’s referring to her current situation now.
But is there always an answer?
Oh, I think a clever girl will find one. Sometimes you just need to repurpose a few things.
And if that doesn’t work?
Leave it to the wind. It’1l eventually blow off whatever’s on the roof.
I’m the one who runs away, though, remember?
But you come back. His words lift Audrey's spirits a little. She glances at key and returns a fragile smile.
Thanks. 14 INT. BOBBY’S GRANDFATHER'S BEDROOM - DAY 14 Bobby helps his GRANDFATHER out of a wheelchair and into
I’m going to meet with the old man this afternoon. His grandfather strains to climb into bed. He coughs, sic He’s on his deathbed.
I quit worrying about that old man thirty years ago. We hated each other but we respected each other.  15 16. He nestles into a comfortable position. Bobby sits at his side.
But you could never get him to sell. Even Dad couldn’t do it.
I don’t want you to end up like your father.
I won’t. I’m gonna show you I can run the business. His grandfather puts his hand on Bobby’s. Reminisces.

What are you gonna do, Bobby? In my day, when you didn’t like someone, you told him to his face, right before you loosened his jaw for him. If he had any guts, he cracked a chair over your head. He coughs. Bobby watches, knowing he’s the last remnant o his family with his grandfather so close to perishing. GRANDFATHER (CONT’D) The old days are gone. Washed away like a creek bed. You can’t just muscle your way around anymore. No one respects guts anymore. He closes his eyes, drifts off. Bobby clutches his hand.
I’m gonna make you proud of me. His grandfather grumbles under his breath.
Thanks for helping me off the shitter. INT. JAWARI’S CAR - MOVING - DAY 15 Rainy finishes off a beer.
We need some more beer. You got any money?  16 17.
I will after we get this job done.
We need some money now.

Jawari’s car pulls to a stop at a red light. Rainy’s elbo hangs out the open window. He looks over at the driver of car in the next lane. It's a pretty blonde woman, 20s. NOTTA CHANCE. Her window partially up and there’s a splotch of birdshit on it.
What’s your name, darlin’? She gives Rainy a cold sneer.
Notta.
Notta. Is that Mexican?
No.
Notta what?
Notta chance. Jawari bursts out laughing. Rainy glances at him, turns playfully back to Notta.
You got birdshit on your window.
Why don’t you lick it off? Rainy hangs out the window.
You think I won’t? A sly grin sneaks onto Notta’s face. She’s game.  18.
I’‘1l give you ten dollars if you lick that birdshit off. Rainy climbs out. The light turns green.
Hey, come on, man. The light turned green. Rainy steps toward Notta’s car.
Bitch, do you even have ten dollars? He gets close enough to see down into Notta’s car. She pu a ten dollar bill from her wallet. Rainy sees she has a l more money. She waves the ten.

I don’t believe you'll do it. He looks into her eyes with a smart aleck smirk as he sti his tongue out and... licks that birdshit off her window it’s chocolate and whipped cream. Notta’s mouth falls open.

Mmmmmmmmmmn. Now gimme my money. Notta, still shocked, holds out the ten. Rainy grabs it w one hand and with the other... slings open a balisong (a. a butterfly knife), presses the blade against Notta’s thr
I’ll take the rest of it too. Jawari sees what’s going on from his car. Scans, panicked
What are you doing, man? Let’s get out of here. Notta holds up the wallet. Rainy grabs it, backs away.
Remember, I got your address. If you call the police, you better hope they find me before I find you. As he climbs into Jawari’s car, Notta can’t help but ask.  17 19.
If you were going to rob me, why did you lick the birdshit off my window? Rainy hangs out the window as Jawari pulls away.
That's just somethin’ for you to remember me by, darlin’. He laughs like a crazy man as they drive off. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - MOVING - DAY 17 Audrey bickers with an upset Cheyenne.
I’m sorry I didn’t say anything before. It’s not set in stone.
What about school? Will I still go to the same school?
No.
What about all my friends?
Honey, I don’t know what’s going to happen. All I know is we can’t afford the rent anymore.
What about dad? Can we ask him to help us?
Your dad doesn’t give us any money. Cheyenne’s eyes well with tears.
But if he knew we might lose our home, then he might.
All he'd do is try and take you away from me. (MORE )
Is that what you want? To live with your dad? You’d still have to change schools. It gets really quiet for several moments. Both Audrey and Cheyenne gaze ahead, pondering. Then...
I know the birthday cards from dad are really from you. Audrey glances between Cheyenne and the road, surprised.
How do you know that?
No postage stamps or return address. So you can’t threaten me with living with dad. I already know he wouldn’t take me. Audrey smiles, bittersweet, at Cheyenne.
You’re pretty smart, you know that?
Yes. Just don’t put a bumper sticker on the car about it. They share a laugh.
Jawari’s car pulls up the driveway, parks behind the hous 19 INT. JAWARI’S CAR - DAY 19 Jawari and Rainy scan the area.
This place is a piece of shit.
Yeah, but there’s supposedly a lot of water around here.
Seems weird Bobby would go through all this trouble for some water.  21.
He’s just trying to impress his grandfather.
Jawari and Rainy get out. Jawari puts his gun in his jack Rainy hangs his rifle over his shoulder.
You have to carry that out in the open?
I‘1l stick it down in my pants. (grabs his crotch) Nobody will see it next to my dick. Jawari rolls his eyes. They walk toward the back door.
Where’s yours?
If it was up your ass, I bet you’d know where it was.
Damn, brother, what spoiled your taco?
(defensive) Taco? What do you mean by taco?
Ain’t that what they eat down there in Dominica or wherever?
Fuck you, man. They arrive at the door. Jawari knocks. They wait idly.
So how long did it take you to smear that doo-doo across your lip? Jawari rubs his moustache, self-satisfied.
Shit, I shave twice a day.  22. Rainy bangs on the door.
Open up, old man! We know you’re in there! (re: Jawari’s moustache) If you shave twice a day, I shit gold bricks. You could hardly tickle a twat with that Velcro looking thing.
You can kiss my damn ass, cowboy. I get more pussy than you can imagine.
Well, if we’re counting imaginary pussy, then I guess you’re gonna win. Rainy bangs on the door again.
You’re not fooling anyone! We know you’re in there! A few more moments go by.
I don’t think he’s in there. Jawari turns and scans the grounds.
He must be around here somewhere. The two men spread out as they approach the barn.
You check the woods on that side and come up behind the barn. I’11 check the other side and come up by that woodpile. Rainy stops near a tree while Jawari is still close by.
I hate trees.
How can you hate trees? No one hates trees.  21 22 23.
I do. Once when I was hiding out from the police, I was stuck in the woods for weeks. Nothin’ but goddamn trees everywhere.
No one hates trees, man. It’s impossible.
Fuck trees. Rainy looks up the tall tree with contempt.
Know what I’m gonna do? I’m gonna piss on this goddamn tree. Rainy unzips his pants, and true to his word, starts peei on the tree. He flips the tree off.
Fuck you, tree. Jawari shakes his head and moves on.
Audrey’s car crunches gravel along the road toward the fa stirring up dust and pinging rocks off the fender wells. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 22 Dust floats past the windows.

I’‘1l never get used to all this dust. I hope the gravel doesn’t tear the car up. They pull up next to a large mailbox. Audrey lowers the window, opens the box. It’s filled with letters and newspapers. Audrey takes them in. AUDREY (CONT’D) We've got to cancel Grandpa’s paper.
The mailbox is so big.  23 24 25 24.
We could live in the mailbox if the house doesn’t work out. They giggle as Audrey raises the window.
Audrey's car pulls up the driveway and parks behind Jawar INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 24 Audrey studies Jawari'’s car, confused.
Whose car is that, Mom?
I don’t know.
Audrey and Cheyenne get out of the car. Audrey pulls out key as she walks toward the door.
Maybe it’s someone from the lumber company. I think Grandpa was going to thin the forest. Cheyenne separates, toward an apple tree in the back yard AUDREY (CONT’D) Don’t you want to see inside?
I just want to see the apples. Audrey arrives at the door, unlocks it.

Okay, but don’t eat any apples until you let me check them out first. Then... the massive TWEETING of a large covey of quail gr Audrey’s attention. She turns to see the birds filling th trees. She steps away from the house, calls out.  26 25. AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne, I told you not to bother the birds!
I’m right here, Mom. Audrey looks toward a bush near the apple tree. There’s Cheyenne, looking right at her. Audrey isn’t sure what to think. She looks toward the woodpile with an uneasy feeling.
Wait here. Audrey cautiously approaches the woodpile, scanning.

head_text.subj: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BARN

text: Rainy hides in the back. Jawari is crouched behind the woodpile. Rainy peeks around the corner and pulls back. Jawari peeks through an opening in the woodpile. Audrey stoops a little as she steps nearer. She searches woodpile until she lays her eyes... Directly on Jawari’s. Audrey’s eyes widen in terror. Jawari stands. Audrey turns and runs, screaming... AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne, get in the car! Get in the car and lock the door! Cheyenne sees Jawari chasing her mother. She reacts quick Climbs into the car and locks the door. INT. AUDREY’S CAR - DAY 26 Cheyenne clambers to the driver’s side and opens the door She locks it again, then pushes it wide open. She barely makes it back over before Audrey scrambles in. Audrey slams the door just as Jawari reaches for the latc
(outside) Open the door! Open the door! Audrey fumbles for her keys in a panic. Drops them in the passenger floorboard. Cheyenne grabs them, finds the key.  27 26.
Here it is! Jawari bangs on the window as Audrey gropes the ignition. Manages to get the key in and start the car.
Open up! We’re not gonna hurt you! Audrey backs up with Jawari following, banging on the roo
We’re not gonna hurt you! Audrey works the shifter into drive. As she starts to pul forward... Rainy appears at the passenger side window with the rifle aimed directly at Cheyenne.
Stop the car or I'll kill the kid. Audrey freezes instantly, horrified.
Put the car into park. Audrey hesitates. Not defiantly but paralyzed with fear. Rainy aims upward. BANG! Fires off a round, then aims at Cheyenne again.
That was a fucking warning shot. Put the car into park or I'll shoot her. Audrey struggles to get her bearings. Puts the shifter in park. Rainy keeps his rifle trained on Cheyenne.
Unlock the door. Audrey fights to focus, then unlocks her door.
Jawari opens the door.
Get out.  28 27. He takes her by the arm as she climbs out. Looks at Rainy
What are we gonna do with them? Rainy lowers his rifle.
You see any rope around here?

Rustic charm, fallen into disarray. Dusty unkempt furnitu deteriorated over years of wear and neglect. Audrey and Cheyenne, both with their hands bound behind t are marshalled into the kitchen and family room area. It’ small the kitchen table is adjacent to the couch. Rainy pushes Audrey onto the couch. Cheyenne sits beside Rainy tosses the extra rope onto the table. Kneels in fro of Cheyenne.
Let’s start with names. I know you’re Cheyenne. That’s a pretty name. Is it because you’re shy? Cheyenne shakes her head. Rainy’s attention turns to Audr
What’s your name? Audrey is so scared, her mouth is dry when she speaks.
Audrey.
Audrey? That’s not that pretty. What’s your middle name?
Michelle.
Michelle. That’s much better. He looks up playfully at Jawari.
(sings Beatles’ song) Michelle. Ma belle.  28. He laughs. Jawari keeps a stony face.
Hey, man, can I talk to you?
In a minute. (to Audrey) Where’s the old man? Audrey absorbs a moment, confused as to what they want.
Grandpa?
Yeah, Grandpa.
He died. Jawari steps forward.
Died? Who owns the water rights?
Water rights? I don’t know. Whoever he left them to, I guess.
When will we find out who gets ‘em?
The will gets read next week. Rainy stands.
We can’t watch them for a whole week. Jawari steps toward the next room.

Let’s talk. They go into the...  29 29. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 29 It's as large as the other two rooms put together, with a large open space in the middle of the floor. Jawari faces Rainy so they can talk privately.
Okay, first off, I don’t like you pointing a rifle at a kid.
Really? The old man was once a kid. Audrey was once a kid. If someone’s seventeen and turns eighteen tomorrow, do I have to wait until tomorrow for it to be okay to point a rifle at them?
I’ve had it with your smartass bullshit.
I’ve had it with your pussyfooting.
Hey, fuck you, cowboy.
Fuck you, Zulu.
Hey, I was born in America, dumb shit. And do you even know what a Zulu is?
Yeah, he’s the guy who spends all day playing with chicken bones ‘cause he’s got the best drugs.
That’s a sangoma, dumbass.
It’s all ooga booga shit to me, buddy. They stare holes into each other another moment, then loo toward the next room.
What are we gonna do with them?  30.
Jawari and Rainy return.
(to Audrey) If you'll sign the water rights over, we'll let you go.
We don’t even know if she'll get them. Jawari keeps his gaze fixed on Audrey.
If she does, then we’ll already have the contract. How about it? Audrey stares, confused a moment, then gently nods.
Okay.
Bobby will be by in a bit with the papers. You sign and that’s it. Rainy kneels in front of Cheyenne.
What about you, shy one? You know anything about this? She shakes her head.
(to Audrey) Does she talk?
She’s scared.
(to Cheyenne) You mad at me because I pointed a rifle at you? Cheyenne nods.
Yeah, well, if you don’t talk, I’m gonna aim it at you again. And this time, I might fire it.  31.
Damn it, Rainy, I told you not to threaten the kid with a rifle.
You said you didn’t want me to point it at her. Did I point it at her? (to Cheyenne) Go on, shy one. Cheyenne looks to her mother for approval.
Go ahead and answer him, sweetie.
Mom and me can’t afford rent so we thought we might move in here.
Well, now, that’s interesting. How do you know you’ll get the house?
We don’t.
Was I talking to you? Let her answer.
Mr. Pendleton said we’1ll probably get it because Grandpa was a hermit and didn’t have much family left. Jawari reaches into his jacket.
So that’s it then. She’1ll probably get the water rights too. Problem solved. He pulls out his gun. Sets it on the table as he sits.
All we have to do is wait for Bobby. Rainy swaggers to the refrigerator. Noses around inside.
I need a fucking beer.  32. He goes through the cupboards.
Damn. What did the old man eat? Chipped paint? There’s more mouse shit than food in these cupboards.
He was ninety. Maybe mouse shit was his secret to longevity. Why don’t you eat some, cowboy?
You think I won’t? How much?
I told you, I don’t have any money. You got some beer in the car, remember?
Oh, that’s right. Why don’t you go get it for me?
Fuck you. Rainy playfully checks out Audrey.

Were you popular in high school?
That's completely subjective. Rainy wags his finger at her as he leans forward.
No. No, see, it’s not. Whether or not you were popular in high school will tell me virtually everything about you.
How is that?
Because high school is where people are shaped for the rest of their lives. What you were then versus what you are now tells me everything. Audrey muses over those words a moment.
Well, I don’t know whether I would be considered popular or not.
Yes, you do. People know whether or not they were popular in high school. Audrey pauses, hesitant to answer.
I was valedictorian. Rainy leans back excitedly.
I knew there was something about you. And now you’re a waitress. See, that tells me a lot. Did you go to college?  63. Audrey answers with an air of sadness.
I went for a couple of years but had to drop out. Rainy puts the joint out. It’s nearly finished now anyway
Look how much we’ve learned in just four questions. You were valedictorian. You dropped out of college and became a waitress. Rainy leans forward with a telling smirk.
And don't think I didn’t notice the wording. You “had to” drop out. Not “I dropped out.” But “had to.”
It doesn’t mean anything. Lots of people drop out of college.
Not lots of valedictorians.
It had more to do with money than anything else.
A valedictorian who can’t get a scholarship?
Is that your final question?
No. My final question is... He ponders. His eyes rest on... Cheyenne.
My final question is, did you drop out because you were pregnant? Audrey gazes at him, stunned speechless. She looks at Cheyenne. Cheyenne looks up at her mother.
Cheyenne is the best thing that ever happened to me.  64. Rainy sighs, annoyed.
That’s what every parent says. That’s such a generic load of bullshit. He leans toward Cheyenne.
Let me tell you something, shy one. People lie like lies will magically turn to money. And no one lies more than parents.
Sounds like someone had a bad childhood. Rainy smirks.
Kids come from fuckin’. So don’t act like you did somethin’ noble.
Do you have to talk that way in front of Cheyenne? Rainy shifts his focus back to Cheyenne.
Parents have babies for two reasons. They can’t control themselves sexually and babies are cute. Rainy’s aggression unsettles Cheyenne. Her eyes well up.
But babies grow up. And as they do, the shine wears off. Then parents start resenting the burden. That’s all parents.
Leave her alone. Cheyenne starts crying. AUDREY (CONT’D) That’s not true, Cheyenne.  65.

It is true. All parents reach a point where they long for the freedom they once had. They secretly dream of all the things they might have achieved if they weren’t stuck. Audrey looks at Cheyenne, desperate to comfort her.
That’s not true. I’ve never once regretted having you.
See, Audrey, you’re just like everyone else. Why can’t you just be honest?

You’ve had your last question. Now it’s my turn to answer. She looks down at a tearful Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) This is the truth, Cheyenne, I swear. Yes, I’ve had regrets in life. I’ve screwed up a lot of things. But I screwed them up. Not you. She looks up at Rainy. AUDREY (CONT’D) It's true. I got pregnant in college. I dropped out because I couldn't afford it. Nostalgia washes over her face. AUDREY (CONT’D) I didn’t know what I wanted to do with my life anyway. Motherhood seemed as good a purpose as any. Audrey's eyes meet with Cheyenne’s. AUDREY (CONT’D) It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. It was tough and I barely scraped by. I thought so many times I’d never make it. But I swear, I never once regretted it.  66. Cheyenne faintly smiles. Rainy gauges Audrey, unconvinced
There’s something you’re not telling us. Cheyenne looks indignantly toward Rainy.
Why are you so mean? Jawari laughs as he pulls out a straw.
Yeah, cowboy, why don’t you tell us about your family? He snorts a line of coke off the table. Sniffs and tweaks nose.
I’‘1l1 tell you about my family if you'll give me a couple of lines. Jawari nods.
Okay. I gotta hear this.
Well, I wasn’t no high school valedictorian, I can tell you that. He and Jawari snicker.
My old man was a con artist.
Why am I not surprised?
We travelled from place to place all the time. I was helping him run a shell game when I was only six. Jawari laughs.
Little Rainy.  67.
I remember he broke into a used car lot office to steal keys one Sunday afternoon. And some people showed up thinking the lot was open. He sold ‘em a car.
He sold ‘em a car? Rainy drifts off. Shakes his head in disbelief.
He filled out the paperwork and everything. He even pretended to call and check on their credit. He looks up at Jawari, still in awe after all these years
The banks weren’t even open.
Damn, Rainy, your old man had a big set of balls on him.
I asked him why he did it and he just said, “I don’t know, I just wanted to see where it went.”
Where was your mother? Rainy snaps out of his trance, looks at Audrey.
I never knew her. Jawari snorts another line. Raises his head, twitching.
So you just ran around with your dad? That’s pretty cool. Rainy drifts off again. This time there’s something eerie about the whole thing.

When I was twelve, we broke into a house to rob the place. There was just supposed to be a woman alone. My dad made me wait in the living room. I could hear her begging.  68. Audrey swallows, nervous about where this is going. David Jawari both have the same look.

Then I heard these noises. I didn’t really know what it was at the time. Then her husband came home. I ran to get my dad. When I opened the door, I saw him on top of her. He was so mad. Rainy sinks deeper into the memory.
He threw a pillow at me. Told me to get out. I guess the pillow hitting a lamp let her husband know we were there. He got a gun. Rainy’s eyes look as if he’s there, witnessing it all ove

I climbed out the window first and hid in the bushes. I heard a shot. I saw my dad hit the ground. He just looked at me. His eyes were open but I could tell he was dead. Jawari gazes at Rainy, spellbound.
Wow. That’s fucked up, man.
I went to a state house. I’ve been a menace to society ever since. He chuckles. Stops laughing when David speaks.
“Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.”
Is that from the Bible?
Jesus said it. When they came to arrest him, one of his disciples cut off the ear of the high priest’s servant. Jesus put the ear back on and said those words.  69.
Jesus put someone’s ear back on? After it was cut off? Rainy glares, fighting to contain a dark fury.
Give me some Kool-Aid and a glass of water and I’1l show you how to turn water into wine.
Jesus’s miracles are documented.
By who? His disciples? The same people who made a living off him? That's a little like Copperfield’s cable pullers claiming he can really fly, isn’t it?
There were others. Jesus healed people.
Ever hear of the immune system?
The immune system can’t make the blind see.
Ever hear of a setup? You fake stuff for money.
All those people wouldn't lie.
‘Cause people are known for their honesty, right? David pauses, musing. Looks away.
Wanna see a magic trick? I bet I can make a line of coke disappear. (to Jawari) What do you say, bro? Look, I’11 put the rifle down. Rainy lays his rifle on the floor. Holds up the knife.  70.
I’‘1l put the knife down. He sets it on the stove-top and shows his hand empty, fro and back. Holds up the log.
I’1l put the log down. He sets the log down NEXT TO THE KNIFE. Raises his hand t show it empty, PALM SIDE ONLY.

I need something to help me relax after all this emotional outpouring. As he says this, we move behind him where we see... the k blade is clipped between his middle fingers, hidden from view. Jawari laughs, oblivious.
Okay, come on. You earned it. Rainy slowly approaches, hands still in the air.

Did I ever tell you why I was on the run from the police when I spent all those weeks in the woods? Jawari shakes his head, holds a straw out. Rainy reaches it with his empty hand. With his other hand, he... Flicks his wrist, slinging the knife into his hand.
Murder. He grabs Jawari’s hand as he stabs him in the gut. Jawari grunts, doubles over. The hostages stiffen, horrified.

I killed my ex girlfriend and her lover. I had to change my identity and everything. He lets go. Jawari slumps over, leaving Rainy with a bloo knife in one hand and the straw in the other. He snorts a line off the table. Shakes his head, twitching.
That's what I’m talkin’ about.  71. Jawari shoves Rainy away. Grabs his switchblade and start push the button. Rainy puts his hand over it... BING. The spring releases but the blade doesn’t emerge.
See, the thing about switchblades, the blade has to lock. He stabs Jawari in the gut again. Jawari grunts. Rainy steps back. Jawari turns the knife handle upside do The blade limply slides out.

If something blocks it on the way out, it’s like a limp dick. I told you balisongs were better. Jawari carefully grabs the blade with index finger and th Pulls it out until it locks with a CLICK. He looks up at Rainy, face pale. Sweating. Quivering.
What’s a matter, Zulu? You look a little peaked. Jawari raises his blade. The two men square off for a kni fight. Rainy laughs playfully.
This is one of those "what if" scenarios, like what happens when a shark meets a killer whale? He waves his knife.
I’m the killer whale and you’re the shark. Jawari takes a meager stab at Rainy and misses. Rainy sla Jawari’s arm. Jawari yells.
Looks like the killer whale is winning. Rainy stabs Jawari in the stomach. Twists the blade. Jawa eyes have a look of certain death.

That’s the same look my daddy had.  72. Jawari slumps to the floor by the table. Rainy kneels, wi the blood on the back of Jawari’s shirt. When he stands, he folds the knife and puts it away. Snor another line. He raises his head, sniffing and fidgeting. Audrey and th others watch, panicked. Rainy picks up the magazine.
Please don’t hurt us. Rainy steps toward the recliner.
My giraffe’s not good enough for you, remember? He grabs the rifle. Inserts the magazine.
I’‘1l do anything you want. Just don’t hurt Cheyenne. David sits forward.
Look, there was no reason for this to escalate to murder. There still isn’t. He may still be alive. Rainy glances at Jawari. Slides a round in the chamber.
Thanks for pointing that out, David. BANG! He shoots Jawari in the back. The hostages avert th eyes.
This is just sell-out central around here today, isn’t it? First Audrey drags you into it. Then you try to weasel out of helping her. Now you want to make sure Jawari is dead.
I didn’t mean it like that.  73.
What you mean is to keep yourself alive. Even at the expense of poor Audrey and Cheyenne here. He aims the rifle at David.

So I‘1l tell you what I want you to do. I want you to pick someone. Whoever you pick gets killed and the other two can live. Which one’s it gonna be, David? David fights to keep composed. Sweat beads on his forehea
I can’t make that choice.
Oh, but you must. You’re the one who goes around door to door asking everyone to make the most important decision of their lives right there on the spot.
I can't.
You better. David's eyes dart around. His mind races for a way out. Finally, he relents.
No. I won’t choose.
All right, then. I’11 make you choose. Rainy trains the barrel directly at Cheyenne’s face.
No. Please. Don’t hurt my daughter.
Shut up.
Shoot me!  46 47 74.

Shut up! You’re too good for me! Then... David leaps from the couch and runs. Rainy aims. David reaches the threshold to the... LIVING ROOM —- DAY 46 BANG! A bullet rips through his knee. David groans as he tumbles to the floor. Rainy storms into the room.
You cowardly piece of shit! He pulls David up, leans him against the doorframe.
Rainy tromps to Cheyenne and aims at her face again. Tear stream down the little girl’s cheeks.

(to David) I’m going to count down from ten to one. You're going to choose between yourself and Audrey. If you don’t make a choice by the time I get to one, then your choice is Cheyenne. Audrey bawls helplessly.
Please don’t hurt my daughter.
Shut up! You don’t get a choice. The choice is David’s. Are you ready, David?
Please... David tries to move his leg. Yells in pain.
Here we go. Audrey begs while Rainy counts. We cut back and forth bet the faces of all of them.  75.
Ten... nine... eight... Please! No! I’m begging seven... six... five. you. I’11 do anything. No!
four... three... two... Shoot me! Shoot me! David softly murmurs...
Shoot me. Rainy pauses. Turns to David, lowering his rifle.
What’s that?
Shoot me. Rainy approaches him.
I’m impressed. You finally grew some balls. He raises the rifle to David’s face.
I’1l give you one last chance to change your mind. David looks at Audrey, his face quivering.
I’m sorry. He’s right. I’ve been a coward. I was afraid. I’ve been afraid my whole life. Always running away. He looks up at Rainy, courage filling his face.
I’m not afraid anymore. Rainy braces the stock against his shoulder.
Look at the bright side. You won’t have to go door to door no more. Audrey's voice cuts across the room.

I was raped.  76. Everyone turns toward Audrey. The room seems to freeze th way for a moment. Audrey fights back a flood of emotions. AUDREY (CONT’D) In college. At a frat party. I was smart enough to get a scholarship and dumb enough to think this guy cared about me. Her eyes turn glassy. Like she can see it all again. AUDREY (CONT’D) I wanted to impress him. I was nervous and I drank too much. The music was so loud. There were so many people. It was hot and stuffy. I got nauseous, so I asked him where the bathroom was. I remember tripping on the stairs. He caught me and we laughed at how tipsy I was. I trusted him. (getting more immersed) When he pushed me on the bed, I didn’t even know where I was at first. The room was spinning. When I told him to stop, he said it was my idea. I remember his weight. The pressure. I couldn’t move. I could barely breathe. I felt like I was in a coffin. But he wouldn’t stop. She pops back to the present, glances around. AUDREY (CONT’D) I turned him in to the president. It was his word against mine and he said it was consensual. When I wouldn’t let it go, I was expelled. She pauses, staring into empty space. AUDREY (CONT’D) I just left. I just gave up. I thought my life was over. Tears well in Audrey’s eyes as they fix on Cheyenne. AUDREY (CONT’D) And then the day came when I saw her. They put her in my arms and it was like... she was magical or something. (MORE)

She was so small and frail and she needed me to take care of her. She looks up at Rainy, teary-eyed. AUDREY (CONT’D) So I carried on. The days went by and things got a little easier. Then one day I realized... she saved my life. Audrey turns sadly to Cheyenne. This is the big one. It’s scary but it’s time to confess the whole story. AUDREY (CONT’D) Thomas, the man you know as your father, was my first husband. The truth is, the reason he doesn’t pay child support is because he doesn’t have to. After we divorced, he asked if he could still see you and I said yes. He helped us for a while but after he remarried, he... he quit. Finally, the floodgates give way and Audrey breaks down. AUDREY (CONT’D) He’s a good man. And I am so sorry I lied to you. Your real father doesn’t want anything to do with you. I was too scared to tell you the truth. Because I’m a coward. Cheyenne’s eyes reach out with the kind of forgiveness on child can offer so quickly.
You’re not a coward, Mom. I forgive you. Rainy sneers. He’s had enough.
Well, didn’t this all just turn into family time. But it doesn’t change a thing. David has already agreed to go the Jesus route.
No one agreed to anything!
Audrey?  48 49 78. She looks at David. He’s filled with a calmness.
It’s okay. Cheyenne manages to get her hands free. She looks toward. the gun, sitting on the table. Rainy raises the barrel toward David, braces the stock against his shoulder once again.
Yeah, see? He wants to do it. Then... Cheyenne jumps from the couch, grabs the gun. It’ big comparatively, she can hardly hold it up. Audrey’s ey widen in horror. Rainy grins.
Do you even know how to use that thing, shy one? BANG! Cheyenne wildly fires toward the ceiling, the kick knocking her down. Pieces of ceiling fall on Rainy.

shit! While Rainy is distracted, Audrey leaps from the couch an rushes at him, screaming. Shoulders him with all her migh They both trip over David’s legs and... LIVING ROOM —- DAY 48 They slam onto the floor. The rifle slides near a buffet table. Rainy grabs Audrey and pulls her down. She kicks h repeatedly. The kicks are ineffective and Rainy laughs.
Oh, darlin’, stop it. You’re turnin’ me on.

Cheyenne climbs to her feet, lugging the gun. David waves over with a nod. She hurries to him. He holds out his bin Cheyenne furiously tugs at them.  50 51 Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 79. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 50 Rainy climbs on top of Audrey, still laughing. Audrey is fighting so hard, it’s about all he can handle.
I love a woman who can wrestle. This goes on until... David raises the gun barrel to Rain temple, ropes still hanging off his wrist.

Get off her. Everything stops. Rainy stares at David. It’s quiet for several moments. Then... From outside, TIRES CRUNCH ACROSS GRAVEL. A car stops in back. A CAR DOOR OPENS. CLOSES. Everyone stays still and quiet. After a few moments, we h the BACK DOOR OPEN. FOOTSTEPS.
Bobby enters carrying a satchel. The first thing he notic is Cheyenne. He looks at her, shocked.
Who the fuck are you?
Cheyenne. Bobby notices David sitting in the doorway to the living with his leg bleeding.
Who the fuck are you?
David. Bobby sees Jawari lying dead on the floor.
What the hell is going on here? He steps so that he can see into the living room. He sees Rainy on top of Audrey on the floor. He sees that David i pointing a gun at Rainy.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 79A.
Rainy?  80.
Uh... we had some issues.
What the goddamn hell is going on here? What happened to Jawari?
We got into it and I accidentally killed him.
That’s not true.
Shut up, Audrey! You don’t know what the hell you’re talking about!
Where’s the old man?
He’s dead. Bobby angrily throws his hands in the air.
Goddamn it! I told you not to kill the old man!
He was already dead.
Well, where is he?
He died four days ago.
The will doesn’t get read ‘til next week. Bobby stares slack-jawed a moment. Glances at David.
Why is this asshole pointing a gun at you?
He got it while I was wrestling with Audrey. She’s probably gonna get the water rights next week.  81. Bobby reaches into his satchel.
Then she can go ahead and sign. He whips out his pistol, points it at David.
First, you can put that gun down. David starts to set the gun down on the living room side.
On the other side. Over here. David sets the gun down on the family room/kitchen side.
Slide it away. David shoves the gun. It slides to a stop a few feet away near the door.
(to Rainy) Get your gun. Rainy grimaces.
It’s a rifle.
I don’t give a good goddamn if it’s Jawari'’s dick, pick it up. Rainy sighs, stays on his knees and leans across the floo grab the rifle.
Untie her. Rainy unties Audrey. Bobby puts his pistol back into his satchel and pulls out a contract. Rainy hands it to Audre Bobby holds out a pen.

Sign it. Rainy hands Audrey the pen. She doesn’t even try to read contract, she just signs it. Rainy hands the items back t Bobby. He stuffs them into his satchel. Lowers the satche David, who eyes it intently.  82.

Now, what you may not realize is that wills are retroactive. It doesn’t matter when it’s read. The date of ownership of bequeathed items legally begins the moment the decedent dies. Bobby looks at Rainy with eyes of cold stone.
I’m going to leave now so you can clean up.
We were promised we'd be let go! He scans between the two rooms, glancing at Jawari.

I wanted things to stay simple but as you’ve seen, Rainy is somewhat of a loose cannon. I think it’s best at this point to just clean up and go home. Then... David grabs Bobby’s satchel, pulls him into the living room. Bobby trips over David’s legs, falls on top Rainy.
Run! Audrey climbs to her feet and jumps over David, grabbing Cheyenne and pulling her along. As Audrey opens the door, Cheyenne snatches the gun off the floor. Rainy gets to his feet, rifle in hand.
Go get them. I’11 watch him. Rainy jumps over David. As he does, David grabs his ankle trips him. Rainy hits the floor, scrambles to his feet. H starts to kick David.
Go on. I’1l take care of him. Bobby kicks David in his injured knee. David screams in agony. Rainy scuttles out the door.  52 83.

Rainy bursts out the door in time to see Audrey and Cheye running away. He aims his rifle. Audrey and Cheyenne barely make it behind the tree that R peed on earlier before... BANG! A bullet smacks a patch o bark off the trunk. Rainy laughs.
Fuckin’ tree! BANG, BANG, BANG, BANG! He fires round after round as he closes in.

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TREE

text: Audrey, back to the trunk, holds Cheyenne tightly to her while bullets riddle the tree. BANG, BANG, BANG! Pieces o bark explode on both sides. Then... silence. Audrey listens. Starts to peek when... Rainy’s face pops up.
Boo! Audrey flinches, screams, quickly tucks Cheyenne behind h
I’m gonna miss you, Audrey. This is the most excitement I’ve had since my daddy tried to drown me.
While Rainy talks, Cheyenne slips the handle of the gun i Audrey’s hand.
Well, that and killin’ my ex girlfriend.
And her lover. Rainy grins.
And her lover. He raises the rifle, calls to the house.  84.
I got ‘em! While he’s distracted, Audrey whips the gun around and po it at him. Rainy does a double-take.
I’ve got a gun too.
Audrey, Audrey, Audrey. I’m disappointed in you. This is a rifle.
I’m sorry. You have a rifle. And I have a gun.

Thank you. But what you don’t have... is the balls. He starts to make a move. It’s cut short... BANG! A bullet streaks by Rainy’s ear, leaving a trail of blood across the side of his head. Audrey screams, taken guard by the recoil. Rainy yells as he’s thrown back. He the ground with a thud.
Come on! She starts to run. Cheyenne grabs the barrel of Rainy’s rifle, jerks her hand back when it burns.
It’s hot. Audrey grabs her.
Let’s go! They head for the barn. Rainy grabs the side of his head.
Audrey, you bitch! Rainy stumbles to his feet. Starts for the barn. Notices tree. Angrily kicks it.
Fuckin’ tree.  53 54 55 85. He turns and staggers toward the barn.
The door creaks open. Rainy peeks in cautiously. Steps in just as cautiously, scanning the area.

I’m impressed, Audrey. I misjudged you. That doesn’t happen often. He steps further in, looking around, assessing. There's a loft above on one side, long abandoned livestock stalls o the other. A door out the back.
I forgot I was dealing with a high school valedictorian. He snickers to himself.
You got guts, Audrey. And you’re smart. And that’s a dangerous combination. He turns, certain she’ll give herself away.

I know you’re in here. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - DAY 54 Audrey waits by the side of the door with a shovel in her hands. Breathing heavily, trying to keep as quiet as she The gun is tucked into her pants.
You could have killed me. But you couldn’t bring yourself to do it.
Rainy nears the back door. He trains his rifle on the lof

You don’t have the kind of guts it takes to kill a man. It’s the eyes. Something about the eyes.  56 57 58 86. BANG! He fires a round into the loft. It blasts a chunk o the old wood into dust, tearing a hole through the floor. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - DAY 56 Audrey flinches at the sound.
I sure hope shy one wasn’t in that loft.
BANG! BANG! BANG! Several holes are blasted into the loft Rainy turns toward the back door.
Where did you go, Audrey? Did you go off into the woods? He starts to step through the doorway.

It's scary out in the woods -- Suddenly, the back of a shovel flies right toward his fac PING! It smacks him square in the nose, knocking his head back. He falters, hits the dirt. Audrey screams, charging with the shovel over her head. She levels it like an axe splitting wood. Rainy puts his arms up to shield himself. CRACK! Right across his forearm. Rainy yells. He tries to his rifle while Audrey draws back again. Just as he aims. Audrey screams, swings like a baseball bat. WHACK! Knocks the rifle out of his hand and into a stall. Rainy manages to grab the shovel’s handle near the scoop. Audrey tries to pull it back. Rainy laughs.
I’m gonna bury you with this shovel. Audrey abandons the shovel, runs out the back door.
Audrey runs for her life. Approaches a bush.  59 60 61 87.
Cheyenne! Cheyenne peeks out from behind the bush. Audrey grabs her hand as she goes by.

Let’s go! The two of them head for the woods. EXT. BARN’S BACK DOOR - MOMENTS LATER 59 Rainy totters out the door with his rifle. He sniffles fr his possibly broken nose and grunts from his busted forea Not to mention the blood across his temple from the bulle
Rainy staggers into the open, near the woodpile. Bobby ha out a window in the living room.
What’s going on out there? Rainy calls out to him.
I think I’m in love!
Quit fuckin’ around! Rainy regains some composure, stomps off toward the woods
Oh, I’m done playing.
Audrey and Cheyenne pause to listen.
The next two shots you hear are gonna be the last!
He’s coming after us. Let’s go. They turn and continue on, deeper into the woods.  62 63 64 88.
Bobby pulls back into the house.
I’m tired of all this messing around. He sits on the buffet. David sits in the doorway. Sweat b on his face and his breathing has become erratic.
I can’t believe you're going to kill a mother and her little girl.
Yeah, well, you’re next, if that helps you forget. He chuckles. David turns away. Notices something.
By Jawari’s body. The switchblade. LIVING ROOM —- DAY 64 David looks back at Bobby. Bobby pulls out a cell phone. Glances at his watch.
I wonder if I still have time to file today with the Water Resources Department. He pauses, looking at David.
The kid was probably just going to be another nobody anyway. Bobby starts dialing. David looks at the switchblade agai Can he sneak to it before Bobby notices?
(phone) Yeah, how late are you open? He climbs off the buffet, leaving his satchel behind.  65 66 67 89.
How long does it take to process a transferral of water rights? He turns his back absentmindedly. David sees his chance.
David crawls across the floor toward Jawari.
Oh really? So there’s really no way I could make it today. David grits his teeth, fighting the pain. Trying to do th as stealthily as he can.

So if I get there first thing tomorrow morning, I could have the rights in my company name before the day is out? David is almost there. Then he notices... eerie silence. pauses. Looks back at the doorway. Nothing. What is Bobby doing? David waits. Waits. Then...
That’s great. I can be there by nine. Can I get your name? The conversation is winding up. David hurries.
Bobby turns around as he speaks.
Thank you, Karen. I’1ll see you -- He stops cold when he sees the empty doorway.
Tomorrow. Bye. He shuts the phone off, eyes blazing. Rushes to the doorw
David is at the front door, reaching for the knob.  68 90.
Trying to escape? What’s the matter with you? Bobby kicks him. David grunts, slides down onto the floor
I can’t believe you thought you could crawl away. Bobby kicks him again. David groans, doubling over.
I should have shot you right from the get-go. He grabs David. Turns him over to pull him up.
Go to hell. David stabs Bobby in the leg with the switchblade. Bobby screams as he falls back onto the floor with the knife st stuck in his leg.

You son of a bitch! David crawls toward the doorway to the living room. It ta all his strength but he desperately forces himself. Bobby grabs the knife handle. Screams as he pulls the bla out. Struggles to climb to his feet. David passes the threshold. Bobby lurches after.
You should have slashed my throat.
David reaches the middle of the floor when Bobby limps in with the switchblade.

You made the same mistake I did. David climbs up the buffet. Reaches for the satchel. Just he touches it... Bobby stabs him right in the back. David cries out. Falls back to the floor. The satchel drops beside him. Some pap slip out. The pistol slides out on top of them.  69 91. Bobby draws back and stabs David in the back again. And again. And again. Until... KINK! The blade breaks off. Bobby sees the broken metal, angrily tosses the handle away. He grabs the pistol. Uses buffet to pull himself to his feet.
I bet you wish you'd killed me from the start now, don’t you? David strains to turn himself over. Looks up at Bobby, quivering. He’s about to die and he knows it.
I don’t have any more regrets. He relents and succumbs.
Audrey and Cheyenne hike through overgrowth. Climb down i a large shallow pit, grown over with grass. In the middle Audrey stops. Looks around, confused.

Wait a minute. Cheyenne stops. Watches her mother. AUDREY (CONT’D) I remember this. This is the reservoir. Or it was. She glances around again, double-checking. AUDREY (CONT’D) The reservoir was right here. I’m sure of it.
What happened to it?
I don’t know. She scans ahead. Points. AUDREY (CONT’D) If I remember right, the creek must be right over there somewhere.  70 71 72 73 92.

Rainy trudges along, searching. He pauses, noticing something. A leaf about the level of his head. He steps closer. Takes the leaf into his hand and sees... blood. He feels his temple. The blood is his own. He smac the leaf aside in frustration.

Fucking circles! He looks down a pathway. The depth of field contracts. Th trees appear to close in. Rainy shakes it off. Looks anot direction. The trees close in that direction too. He looks another direction. Same thing. Then another. Onc again, the trees are closing in. He calls out.
Audrey!
Whirls, hearing him. She turns to Cheyenne.
He’s gotten farther away. He must be going the wrong way. Let’s go. They head into a long stretch of woods, angled downward.
Runs through the forest like a madman. He trips over a ro sticking out. Smacks the ground. He raises his face, then pauses, hearing something. The gentle WHOOSH of water.
The creek. He climbs to his feet, moves its direction.
Reaches the edge of the creek, followed by Cheyenne. They about twenty feet up and it’s a steep drop on both sides.
Should we go downstream? Maybe the water isn’t as deep.  74 75 76 93. Audrey studies the drop, covered with thick exposed roots

No. I think the roots will hold. She climbs down, stepping on roots like crooked ladder ru Audrey pauses when she’s completely over the side. AUDREY (CONT’D) Okay, Cheyenne. Be very careful. I’'ll be right below you. Cheyenne balks, extremely nervous.
I’m scared.
I know you are, sweetie, but we'll be down before you know it.

Forces his way through small branches. Emerges at a large creek bed. Smiles. It’s much lower than where Audrey and Cheyenne are but th bed covers a larger area. Rainy’s footsteps sink in the s bed as he approaches the creek. Rainy drops to his knees at the bank. The creek flows peacefully. Rainy splashes water on his face, upsetting t tranquility.
Keeps one hand free to catch Cheyenne.
Make sure you have your footing before you take your next step. Cheyenne reluctantly places her foot on a root. It slips She screams.
Raises his face, looking upstream. Grins. Grabs his rifle Splashes across the creek to the other side.  77 78 79
Clutches Cheyenne.

It’s okay. I’ve got you. Cheyenne holds onto her mother, paralyzed with fear. AUDREY (CONT’D) Climb onto my back. Cheyenne hesitates. Tries to pull herself together. AUDREY (CONT’D) Come on, Cheyenne. We don’t have time. You can do it. Cheyenne shakily climbs onto Audrey's back. Audrey naviga the roots, struggling with the additional weight. They finally reach the very narrow creek bed. The creek, the other hand, is wide and the water is rushing. Audrey sets Cheyenne down. Surmises.
Are we going to cross it?
I don’t think we have a choice. Audrey climbs down into the water. It’s nearly waist deep AUDREY (CONT’D) Climb on. Cheyenne climbs onto Audrey’s back and Audrey wades acros
Follows the creek on the other side. The whoosh of water faster now. He treks uphill.
Is right at the bank. One more step and she’1ll be there. loses her footing and falls forward. Cheyenne catches the edge of the bank while Audrey goes under.
Mom!  95. Cheyenne’s face fills with panic. She pulls herself onto narrow bank.
Mom! Audrey breaks the surface, gasping. Reaching for the bank

Mom! Cheyenne looks back and sees a root. She grabs it with on hand. Reaches for Audrey’s hand with the other. Smack! Their hands clasp. Cheyenne pulls with all her mig Audrey claws at the bank. With Cheyenne’s help, Audrey Manages to pull herself to the bank. She climbs out of the water. Rests on the bank. Struggles catch her breath. CHEYENNE (CONT’D) What happened?
An undercurrent caught my foot. Cheyenne looks at her mother, shaken by the whole thing.
Are you okay? Audrey nods, still catching her breath.
Thanks.
All we got is each other. Audrey smiles with tears of pride welling in her eyes.
That’s plenty. Let’s go. They pull themselves to their feet. There’s another “root ladder” going up the other side.
I think I can do it myself this time.  80 96.
You sure? (off her nod) Okay, then, go on. I'll be right behind you. Cheyenne starts climbing up the roots.
Just as Cheyenne is about to reach the top... A rifle lowers into her face. Her eyes widen. Audrey, realizing Cheyenne has stopped, looks up to see... Rainy.
What do we have here? This is a regular reunion. Speaking of, you must have had your first high school reunion by now.
I didn't go. Rainy shakes his head.
Well, that’s a shame. And you were valedictorian. I would have thought you would have felt obligated to attend.
I couldn’t get the night off.
Waitress duty called, eh?
I would appreciate it if you would stop pointing that gun in my daughter’s face. Rainy smirks.
Audrey, how many times do I have to tell you? It’s a goddamn rifle. He braces the stock against his shoulder. Desperate, Audr looks toward Cheyenne.  97.
Cheyenne? It’s not hot right now. Cheyenne’s eyes move to the rifle barrel. Rainy smiles playfully, oblivious.
Yes, it is rather nice out here by the creek, isn’t it?
(to Cheyenne) Push it up.
When? Rainy gets suspicious.
What are you two talking about?

Now! Cheyenne grabs the rifle barrel, shoves it upward. From behind, Audrey reaches over and points her gun at Rainy. eyes widen. AUDREY (CONT’D) This is your last warning shot, motherfucker. BANG! Rainy grunts. Looks down. A bloodstain on his shirt over his chest grows with the pump of his heart. He looks Audrey in disbelief. Cheyenne pulls the rifle from his limp hand. It clangs do the drop and splashes into the creek. Rainy stands. Looks at his own blood on his trembling han Struggles to speak.

If it... hadn’t been... for that... fuckin’ tree. He falls over the edge. Tumbles down the drop and splashe into the water. Cheyenne and Audrey climb up into the woods by the drop. Audrey gazes down, stunned by her own actions. After a fe moments, she realizes something.  81 82 83 98.
Okay, step back. She motions for Cheyenne to clear some room.
What are you going to do? Audrey raises the barrel into the air.
There needs to be two shots.
Bobby finishes pulling David's body next to Jawari’s. In distance, there’s a MUFFLED BANG. Bobby looks up.
There went the other one. He limps into the...

He puts his papers back into his satchel. Puts his gun ba in. Takes the phone and dials. INT. BOBBY’S GRANDFATHER'S BEDROOM - DAY 83 RING. Bobby's grandfather grumbles in his sleep, half awakened by the ringing phone. It keeps RINGING until the man finally answers it.
What?

head_text.subj: BOBBY AND HIS GRANDFATHER ON THE PHONE

text: Bobby turns excitedly, hearing his grandfather’s voice.
It’s Bobby.
I was sleeping.
I know but this is important.
Well, it damn well better be.
I got ‘em, Grandpa. I got the water rights. Grandfather recoils in disbelief.
You're jerking my chain.
No. I really got ‘em.
I don’t believe a word of it.
It’s true. I swear. The old man died.
Died? When did that happen?
Four days ago.
Four days ago! I can’t keep up with it anymore. I wish I'd known. I would have gone to the funeral. Or sent flowers or something. Bobby can’t wipe the smile off his face.
I got his granddaughter to sign. Grandfather's face goes blank.
You muscled his granddaughter? Which one?
Who cares? Grandfather asks more sternly this time.
Which one?  100.
Audrey. Grandfather thinks back. Nostalgia fills his face.
Yes, Audrey. I remember little Audrey. I haven’t seen her in years. What’s she doing now?
Who cares? We got the water rights.
You didn’t hurt Audrey, did you? Bobby hesitates, just now realizing he may have screwed u
No. Of course not.
I'd be very upset if anything happened to Audrey.
She’s fine.
I always liked her. If I remember right, she was the one who always liked to rub my whiskers.
Fuck Audrey, okay? She’s fine. Grandfather's face takes on a chilling tone.
Don’t talk to me that way. Bobby turns immediately submissive.
I’m sorry.
I’1l smack your nose around to the other side of your head.
I’m sorry, okay? I didn’t mean it. Audrey's fine, okay? I’m just tryin’ to tell you something.  101. The DOOR OPENS from the next room. Bobby glances that way
I can get the rights transferred tomorrow morning.
Listen, Bobby. You’re next in line. If you screwed this up, it’s over for you.
I didn’t screw it up. It’s fine. Bobby calls out to the next room.
Rainy, hurry up. I gotta get going. You need to clean up before it gets dark. Audrey appears out of the shadows, aiming the gun. Bobby freezes, shocked to see her. Audrey steps into the room.
Hang up the phone.
What’s going on, Bobby?
Nothing. I’1l call you back.
Something's wrong, isn’t it?
No. Everything’s fine. I just gotta get off the phone. Grandfather lowers his head. He knows something’s wrong. last hope for a legacy has just vanished.
You’re just like your father, Bobby. He hangs up.
Bobby disconnects. Drops the phone in the satchel.
No one told you to drop the phone in the satchel.
I’m sorry. You wanted the phone to call the police? Bobby starts to reach in. Audrey raises her gun higher.
Don’t. Bobby stops, frowns. He steps into the open as Audrey ste further in.

Hey, now, I didn’t kill anybody. All I wanted was for you to sign the papers. All I wanted was the water rights. I just told those guys to get the old man to sign. When they found out he was dead, they should have left. I didn’t know what they were gonna do. Audrey fixes the gun on Bobby. He stares down the barrel, visibly shaken. Audrey’s aim is steady. Her face is sure.

I want you to reach in slowly. If you want to live... take out the phone. If you want to die... take out the gun. Bobby vacillates. Then he reaches into the satchel so slo it seems like forever. He nervously clutches something. Audrey watches, wearing a poker face.

Well, I’ve already got the signature. So I guess there’s no sense in any more violence. He raises the satchel with his hand still in it... BANG! Blood spatters as a bullet rips through his chest. groans, wildly raising the satchel into the air.  85 103. BANG! He fires a round, blowing out the side of the satch and into the ceiling. Pieces of ceiling rain down on him. We follow him as he falls back in SLOW MOTION, his face filled with disbelief. All the way until he hits the floo with a RESOUNDING THUMP. Dead.
Audrey ambles out the back door with the gun slack in her hand. Scans the barn and woodpile area as she approaches.
Cheyenne!
Cheyenne peeks out from the bush she hid behind earlier.
Approaches the woodpile. AUDREY (CONT’D) Cheyenne! It’s okay!
Here I am! Cheyenne comes running. Audrey looks at her like it’s the most amazing thing she’s ever seen.
Cheyenne. They run into each other’s arms. Hug tightly, trying to absorb the moment for all it’s worth. AUDREY (CONT’D) I love you.
I love you too. They pull back with bittersweet faces.

We don’t have to live on the farm. Exhausted smiles are as close to giggles as they can mana They slip back into a hug, propping each other up.  86 INT. MR. 104. PENDLETON’S OFFICE - DAY 86 SUPER: “One Week Later.” Mr. Pendleton sits at his desk and reads from a file. He closes

And so this concludes his last will and testament. The house is officially yours. the folder. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) I’m not sure if you'll want to live in it now or not, given all that’s happened. But it’s yours to do with as you please. Are there any questions? Audrey and Cheyenne, dressed nicely, sit across from him. Audrey is
I didn’t hear you mention anything about the water rights.
Water rights? Your grandfather got his water from the district. confused. This is news to her.
But I thought Grandpa’s water was gravity fed from a creek. I remember playing around the reservoir when I was a kid.
Yes, when you were a child, maybe. But he switched to district water over twenty years ago. He was too old to maintain the pipes.
Then who owns the water rights?
The state. The law is that if water rights aren’t exercised for five years or more, they go into forfeiture.  105.
Did Grandpa know this?
I don’t know. He would have been nearly eighty when it went into forfeiture. It’s entirely possible he couldn’t read or understand the notices.
I don’t think he did. So Grandpa couldn’t have sold the water rights even if he wanted to?
He could have gotten them from the state. Anyone could.
You mean those rights were up for grabs for anyone who wanted them?

Yes, anyone. Audrey stares, completely flabbergasted. She can’t proces it. Mr. Pendleton becomes concerned. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Are you okay? She doesn’t answer. She just stares, distant. MR. PENDLETON (CONT’D) Audrey? Finally, Audrey breaks down. She buries her face in her h and cries. It upsets Cheyenne.
What’s wrong?
It'll be all right. You can sell off some of the trees to the sawmill. That should get you by.
Don’'t cry, Mom. As Audrey's “crying” progresses, it becomes more and more evident that she’s not crying at all. She’s laughing.  106.
I’m not crying, sweetie. She raises her face. She’s on the verge of crying, but laughing nonetheless.
What’s so funny?
All they had to do was ask. She keeps laughing and fighting back tears. AUDREY (CONT’D) All they had to do was ask. FADE OUT.
